title: Weird Invisible Symptoms of MS: Part II – Tinnitus

content: If you find yourself saying to others “I beg your pardon” or “Come again” more than usual, it could be a sign of hearing loss. Although not as common, multiple sclerosis can cause a hearing deficit called sensorineural hearing loss due to nerve damage in the brainstem. Sometimes it can be temporary, like during a flare-up, and improve once it ends.

Hearing loss is a common cause of tinnitus – hearing a buzzing or ringing noise in your ears without the influence of external sound. Sometimes it goes inadvertently, especially if it’s only in one ear. That’s exactly what happened to me.

I don’t like earbuds. Actually, I hate them. They just gross me out. But since we live in a virtual world now, in some instances I’ve been forced to wear them completely against my will. Just thinking about it makes me queasy. Oh Lord, I’m so dramatic sometimes.

One day, I was wearing just one earbud, specifically in my left ear, and it sounded soft. I tried adjusting the volume, but it was all the way up. I switched the earbud to my right ear and it was as loud as can be. I kind of freaked out, so I switched it over to my left ear again, and the same thing happened. The volume was low.

One day, I was wearing just one earbud, specifically in my left ear, and it sounded soft. I tried adjusting the volume, but it was all the way up. I switched the earbud to my right ear and it was as loud as can be. I kind of freaked out, so I switched it over to my left ear again, and the same thing happened. The volume was low.

content: That’s how I realized that I can’t hear well out of my left ear. It went unnoticed for a long time because I can hear just fine for the most part when my ears are not covered. It's only when I wear one earbud that I notice that I don't hear the same way from both ears.

I was in a support group meeting here in my area, and this topic came up. One member mentioned that when he’s watching TV and there are people talking in the background, he can’t understand the audio coming from the TV. Or if he’s holding a conversation with somebody and there’s background noise, like the TV playing, he can’t understand what the other person is saying. It sounds distorted.

content_blocks.text: That’s how I realized that I can’t hear well out of my left ear. It went unnoticed for a long time because I can hear just fine for the most part when my ears are not covered. It's only when I wear one earbud that I notice that I don't hear the same way from both ears.

I was in a support group meeting here in my area, and this topic came up. One member mentioned that when he’s watching TV and there are people talking in the background, he can’t understand the audio coming from the TV. Or if he’s holding a conversation with somebody and there’s background noise, like the TV playing, he can’t understand what the other person is saying. It sounds distorted.

content: When he said that, it all came together. I realized that this happens to me, too. I’ve always been very sensitive to noise, so I didn’t think too much of it. I thought it was just that: sensitivity to noise. I just learned that with tinnitus in MS you could experience these symptoms.

content_blocks.text: When he said that, it all came together. I realized that this happens to me, too. I’ve always been very sensitive to noise, so I didn’t think too much of it. I thought it was just that: sensitivity to noise. I just learned that with tinnitus in MS you could experience these symptoms.

content: Hearing loss being a common cause of tinnitus, for someone like me that lives with MS (with nerve damage in the brainstem), it only makes sense. At night when I’m trying to go to sleep, I hear this ringing noise quite loud in my ears, or in my head, I’m not sure. The thing is that I hear it and no one else does.

A friend of mine mentioned that she can hear a buzzing sound inside of her, when in a quiet space. I remember hearing that too for a while, but eventually it stopped. Little did I know that it was associated with a real condition like tinnitus.

I know that when I’m watching TV and my kids start to talk or ask me a question, I can’t understand the TV. I have to pause the show and rewind it because I get confused. It sounds muffled, and honestly, it’s frustrating because it physically affects me. I often get a headache when this happens, especially if they interrupt me more than once.

content_blocks.text: Hearing loss being a common cause of tinnitus, for someone like me that lives with MS (with nerve damage in the brainstem), it only makes sense. At night when I’m trying to go to sleep, I hear this ringing noise quite loud in my ears, or in my head, I’m not sure. The thing is that I hear it and no one else does.

A friend of mine mentioned that she can hear a buzzing sound inside of her, when in a quiet space. I remember hearing that too for a while, but eventually it stopped. Little did I know that it was associated with a real condition like tinnitus.

I know that when I’m watching TV and my kids start to talk or ask me a question, I can’t understand the TV. I have to pause the show and rewind it because I get confused. It sounds muffled, and honestly, it’s frustrating because it physically affects me. I often get a headache when this happens, especially if they interrupt me more than once.

content: People around me get very frustrated with me and my sensitivity to noise. I constantly complain. Either it’s too loud, or I’m telling everyone to be quiet because I can’t hear, or I’m getting a headache. Lately, I’ve noticed that I can’t even go to a restaurant anymore because of the talking, the sound of the utensils, the music – everything bothers me. All noises are amplified.

I try my best to dodge every curveball MS throws at me, so I have an emergency plan for when the noise gets to me. I wear silicone ear plugs. They dampen the intensity of the noise and they’re clear, so nobody can notice them.

content_blocks.text: People around me get very frustrated with me and my sensitivity to noise. I constantly complain. Either it’s too loud, or I’m telling everyone to be quiet because I can’t hear, or I’m getting a headache. Lately, I’ve noticed that I can’t even go to a restaurant anymore because of the talking, the sound of the utensils, the music – everything bothers me. All noises are amplified.

I try my best to dodge every curveball MS throws at me, so I have an emergency plan for when the noise gets to me. I wear silicone ear plugs. They dampen the intensity of the noise and they’re clear, so nobody can notice them.

content: When I have ringing in my ears I use a different technique. I either sing, whistle, or listen to music to distract my brain (kind of like “white noise”). Basically, I hinder the effect of noise with some more noise. It’s kind of hard to find the logic behind it, but it works for me. MS is crazy!

content_blocks.text: When I have ringing in my ears I use a different technique. I either sing, whistle, or listen to music to distract my brain (kind of like “white noise”). Basically, I hinder the effect of noise with some more noise. It’s kind of hard to find the logic behind it, but it works for me. MS is crazy!

content: Technically tinnitus would not be a direct symptom of MS but a consequence of hearing loss caused by nerve damage in the brainstem and the interruption in the pathways of sound through where the electrical impulses are sent to the brain.

There are numerous things that the doctors won’t tell you or that they can’t even foresee will happen to you, or that we’re in for a journey full of surprises. And hang tight, because there’s more to come in my next blog.
